div1.p: I am not surprizedsurprised that you are having a provoking time with KennerlyKennerley. He is a small Englishman with a very large consciousness of himself and his race, was my thought on meeting him once. Small in size, I mean, for he has a cleverness. Tthough I doubt if it is broadly based, or soundly; unless a cool, or seemingly cool, egotism is sufficient for a foundation for such intellectuality as he gives the impression of believing himself to possess. I too have had my my oundround with with publishing difficulties, as I will tell you inddetail some day.

But as you say Browning's line is the right gospel, though 'welcomeing each rebusff.' when one is on the ragged edge, gets rather trying when the rebuffs turn up too often. I hope that one concerned with the subsistence problem may not trouble you much longer. I have had to sweep many devils out of my house, but not that one for a very long at a time. A year or two of eteaching, till my people realized it was poetry or bust with me, and it was out for good, I hope.

As for the matter of faith, not to have it is to go against the current of life, which is upward, no matter from whence it comes or whither it goes. So it is as wise to trust it is forced upon us by some real economy, not by our mere fatuity..

postscript.p: Am sending you the photo of myself. Mrs. Rice's is not yet ready. It's soiled and no doubt will be more so when your paper is through with the plate-making; but you might suggest to them to return it to me — if it's worth sending.
And, by the way, when your article appears send me a copy by letter mail, or it may not be forwarded to me.
